An Achievable Rate Region for Interference Channels
with Conferencing

Yi Cao and Biao Chen Department of EECS, Syracuse University, Syracuse, NY 13244
Email: ycao01@syr.edu, bichen@ecs.syr.edu
Abstract

In this paper, we propose an achievable rate region for discrete memoryless interference channels with conferencing at the transmitter side. We employ superposition block Markov encoding, combined with simultaneous superposition coding, dirty paper coding, and random binning to obtain the achievable rate region. We show that, under respective conditions, the proposed achievable region reduces to Han and Kobayashi‚Äôs achievable region for interference channels, the capacity region for degraded relay channels, and the capacity region for the Gaussian vector broadcast channel. Numerical examples for the Gaussian case are given.

Index terms ‚Äî interference channels, dirty paper coding, superposition block Markov encoding, random binning.

I Introduction

The capacity region of an interference channel (IC), where the information sources at the two transmitters are statistically independent, has been a long standing problem. Carleial was the first to use the superposition code idea [1] to obtain an inner bound for IC. This inner bound was later improved by Han and Kobayashi [2] who gave an achievable rate region that is the largest reported to this date. Recently, a simplified description of the Han-Kobayashi (HK) rate region for the general IC is derived by Chong-Motani-Garg in [3].

A related and less well investigated problem is when the information sources at the two transmitters are correlated, i.e., interference channel with common information (ICCI) [4, 5]. In [4], an achievable rate region, an outer bound, and a limiting expression for the capacity region were obtained. Later, the capacity region of this channel under strong interference was found in [5]. Recently, improved achievable regions for general ICCI [6, 7] and three new outer bounds for the capacity region of Gaussian ICCI [8] were proposed. However, all those results are based on the assumption that the common message is available noncausally.

In this work, we investigate the problem of user cooperation in interference channels for the causal case. Here, each user not only transmits his own message to the intended receiver, but also serves as a relay to help transmit part of the other user‚Äôs message. We apply the superposition block Markov encoding, which was used previously for the relay channel [9] and for user cooperation in multiple access channels [10]. Our proposed achievable rate region is a generalized form of the HK region for IC [2], the capacity region of degraded relay channels [9], and the capacity region of the Gaussian vector broadcast channel (GVBC) [11].

This paper is organized as follows. In section II, we present the channel model and review some existing results. In section III, we propose an achievable region for general IC with transmitter conferencing. In section IV, numerical examples are used to compare the proposed region with the HK region and the capacity region of GVBC. We conclude in section V.

III Main Results

We first give a brief outline of our encoding-decoding strategy. We split each user‚Äôs message into two parts: MùëÄM and WùëäW, where MùëÄM is to be sent directly to the intended receiver, and WùëäW is the cooperative message to be sent to the receiver via the cooperation of the other user (relay). Our cooperation strategy is based on superposition block Markov encoding with the assumption that WùëäW can be perfectly decoded by the relay. The purpose of introducing MùëÄM is to achieve a reasonable rate region (no less than IC without conferencing) even when the conferencing channel is poor. For the message MùëÄM, we apply simultaneous superposition coding [2] and further split it into two parts: private message VùëâV and common message UùëàU.

For the cooperation in transmitting WùëäW, we jointly consider BùêµB blocks, each of nùëõn symbols. Each user transmits a sequence of B‚àí1ùêµ1B-1 messages w1,‚ãØ,wB‚àí1subscriptùë§1‚ãØsubscriptùë§ùêµ1w_{1},\cdot\cdot\cdot,w_{B-1} in BùêµB blocks, with no new message in the last block. Note that as B‚Üí‚àû‚ÜíùêµB\rightarrow\infty, (B‚àí1)/Bùêµ1ùêµ(B-1)/B is arbitrarily close to 111, hence the penalty on rate is negligible. Now we take user 1 as an example to show the whole process. Suppose there are 2n‚ÄãR13superscript2ùëõsubscriptùëÖ132^{nR_{13}} codewords of W1subscriptùëä1W_{1} for user 1 to transmit. We establish a random partition by randomly throwing them into 2n‚ÄãR10superscript2ùëõsubscriptùëÖ102^{nR_{10}} cells. This partition is made known to both transmitters and receivers. Suppose user 1 sends message w1,b‚àí1subscriptùë§1ùëè1w_{1,b-1} at block b‚àí1ùëè1b-1. At the end of block b‚àí1ùëè1b-1, following our assumption, user 2 can perfectly decode w1,b‚àí1subscriptùë§1ùëè1w_{1,b-1} and calculate the cell index s1‚Äãbsubscriptùë†1ùëès_{1b} to which w1,b‚àí1subscriptùë§1ùëè1w_{1,b-1} belongs. At block bùëèb, both user 1 and 2 spend some power transmitting s1‚Äãbsubscriptùë†1ùëès_{1b}. This provides the basis for cooperatively resolving the remaining Y1subscriptùëå1Y_{1} uncertainty about w1,b‚àí1subscriptùë§1ùëè1w_{1,b-1}. After decoding s1‚Äãbsubscriptùë†1ùëès_{1b} at the end of block bùëèb, receiver Y1subscriptùëå1Y_{1} intersects its ambiguity set ùíü‚Äã(y1‚Äã(b‚àí1))ùíüsubscriptùë¶1ùëè1\mathcal{D}(y_{1}(b-1)) (i.e., the set of all codewords wùë§w that are jointly typical with y1,b‚àí1subscriptùë¶1ùëè1y_{1,b-1}[9]) with cell s1‚Äãbsubscriptùë†1ùëès_{1b} and gets the unique correct codeword w1,b‚àí1subscriptùë§1ùëè1w_{1,b-1} with a probability close to 1.

Since both users 1 and 2 can perfectly decode each other‚Äôs messages W1subscriptùëä1W_{1}, W2subscriptùëä2W_{2} and then calculate the corresponding cell indices S1,S2subscriptùëÜ1subscriptùëÜ2S_{1},S_{2}, we can employ dirty paper coding (DPC) to transmit V1,U1subscriptùëâ1subscriptùëà1V_{1},U_{1} and S1subscriptùëÜ1S_{1} treating S2subscriptùëÜ2S_{2} as a known interference at transmitter 1. Similarly at transmitter 2, we can transmit V2,U2subscriptùëâ2subscriptùëà2V_{2},U_{2} and S2subscriptùëÜ2S_{2} treating S1subscriptùëÜ1S_{1} as a known interference. The analysis of Pe,2(n)superscriptsubscriptùëÉùëí2ùëõP_{e,2}^{(n)} is similar to Pe,1(n)superscriptsubscriptùëÉùëí1ùëõP_{e,1}^{(n)}, which leads to bounds (23)-(32). Thus, ‚Ñõ1‚àósuperscriptsubscript‚Ñõ1\mathcal{R}_{1}^{*} is achievable. Proof of ‚Ñõ2‚àósuperscriptsubscript‚Ñõ2\mathcal{R}_{2}^{*} is identical, hence ‚Ñõ‚àósuperscript‚Ñõ\mathcal{R}^{*} is achievable for ICC via time sharing.

The cardinality bound on QùëÑQ, i.e., |Q|‚â§33ùëÑ33|Q|\leq 33 is obtained by applying the Caratheodory Theorem to a set of inequalities that bound the rate pair (R1,R2)subscriptùëÖ1subscriptùëÖ2(R_{1},R_{2}), obtained via Fourier-Motzkin elimination to Eqs. (9)-(32). Q.E.D.

Remarks: From the encoding-decoding strategy of the above theorem, the achievable region ‚Ñõ‚àósuperscript‚Ñõ\mathcal{R}^{*} is actually a generalization of the HK region for IC, the capacity region of degraded relay channels, and the capacity region of GVBC. It reduces to those extreme cases under the conditions elaborated below.

1)When the conferencing channel between the two users is very poor, the bound in (22) and (32) can be very small. In this case, allocating power for cooperation will actually reduce the rates otherwise achievable via direct transmission. As a result, the encoders will not allocate any power to transmit W1subscriptùëä1W_{1} and W2subscriptùëä2W_{2}, so W1=W2=S1=S2=0subscriptùëä1subscriptùëä2subscriptùëÜ1subscriptùëÜ20W_{1}=W_{2}=S_{1}=S_{2}=0 and G1=G2=H1=H2=0subscriptùê∫1subscriptùê∫2subscriptùêª1subscriptùêª20G_{1}=G_{2}=H_{1}=H_{2}=0. Then, both ‚Ñõ1‚àósuperscriptsubscript‚Ñõ1\mathcal{R}_{1}^{*} and ‚Ñõ2‚àósuperscriptsubscript‚Ñõ2\mathcal{R}_{2}^{*} reduce to the region in Proposition 1, which equals to the HK region.

2)When the conferencing channel between the two users is good enough, it is not necessary to transmit messages directly to the receiver, because cooperative transmission with the other user will always yield a better rate. In this case, the encoders will let V1=V2=U1=U2=0subscriptùëâ1subscriptùëâ2subscriptùëà1subscriptùëà20V_{1}=V_{2}=U_{1}=U_{2}=0 and M1=M2=N1=N2=0subscriptùëÄ1subscriptùëÄ2subscriptùëÅ1subscriptùëÅ20M_{1}=M_{2}=N_{1}=N_{2}=0. Now, if user 2 refrains from transmitting its own message and only serves as a relay to user 1 (i.e., W2=S2=G2=H2=0subscriptùëä2subscriptùëÜ2subscriptùê∫2subscriptùêª20W_{2}=S_{2}=G_{2}=H_{2}=0), both ‚Ñõ1‚àósuperscriptsubscript‚Ñõ1\mathcal{R}_{1}^{*} and ‚Ñõ2‚àósuperscriptsubscript‚Ñõ2\mathcal{R}_{2}^{*} reduce to the capacity region of the degraded relay channel in Proposition 2. Similarly, if user 1 serves only as a relay to user 2, it also reduces to the capacity region of the degraded relay channel.

3)When the conferencing channel between the two users is ideal (i.e., the conferencing channel capacity is infinite), the bounds in (22) and (32) are no longer needed. So, W1=W2=G1=G2‚âà0subscriptùëä1subscriptùëä2subscriptùê∫1subscriptùê∫20W_{1}=W_{2}=G_{1}=G_{2}\approx 0. Combining the result in case 2 that V1=V2=U1=U2=0subscriptùëâ1subscriptùëâ2subscriptùëà1subscriptùëà20V_{1}=V_{2}=U_{1}=U_{2}=0 and M1=M2=N1=N2=0subscriptùëÄ1subscriptùëÄ2subscriptùëÅ1subscriptùëÅ20M_{1}=M_{2}=N_{1}=N_{2}=0, we can easily check that ‚Ñõ1‚àósuperscriptsubscript‚Ñõ1\mathcal{R}_{1}^{*} reduces to

R1subscriptùëÖ1\displaystyle R_{1} ‚â§\displaystyle\leq I‚Äã(Y1;H1|Q)‚àíI‚Äã(H1;S2|Q)ùêºsubscriptùëå1conditionalsubscriptùêª1ùëÑùêºsubscriptùêª1conditionalsubscriptùëÜ2ùëÑ\displaystyle I(Y_{1};H_{1}|Q)-I(H_{1};S_{2}|Q) (51)
R2subscriptùëÖ2\displaystyle R_{2} ‚â§\displaystyle\leq I‚Äã(Y2;S2|Q)ùêºsubscriptùëå2conditionalsubscriptùëÜ2ùëÑ\displaystyle I(Y_{2};S_{2}|Q) (52)

and ‚Ñõ2‚àósuperscriptsubscript‚Ñõ2\mathcal{R}_{2}^{*} reduces to

R1subscriptùëÖ1\displaystyle R_{1} ‚â§\displaystyle\leq I‚Äã(Y1;S1|Q)ùêºsubscriptùëå1conditionalsubscriptùëÜ1ùëÑ\displaystyle I(Y_{1};S_{1}|Q) (53)
R2subscriptùëÖ2\displaystyle R_{2} ‚â§\displaystyle\leq I‚Äã(Y2;H2|Q)‚àíI‚Äã(H2;S1|Q)ùêºsubscriptùëå2conditionalsubscriptùêª2ùëÑùêºsubscriptùêª2conditionalsubscriptùëÜ1ùëÑ\displaystyle I(Y_{2};H_{2}|Q)-I(H_{2};S_{1}|Q) (54)

For the Gaussian case, the rate region (51)-(52) becomes (6) and (53)-(54) becomes (7). So, in this case, ‚Ñõ‚àósuperscript‚Ñõ\mathcal{R}^{*} reduces to the capacity region of GVBC.

4)During the review process of this paper, we became aware of [12], which essentially tackles the same problem using a different approach. In [12], user cooperation results in a common information (in the sense of [4]) at the encoders and the decoder uses backward decoding (similar to that of [10]) instead of the random partitioning (i.e., binning) we use in our approach. Except for some extreme cases, it appears no subset relation can be established. The obtained achievable region in [12] is simpler as it does not involve a large number of auxiliary variables; however, the scheme in [12] is strictly suboptimal for certain extreme cases (e.g., degraded relay channels, IC with degraded message sets with weak interference, and MIMO BC) whereas our achievable region can be easily shown to be optimal in each of these cases.

IV Numerical Examples

The standard form of a Gaussian interference channel is:

Y1subscriptùëå1\displaystyle Y_{1} =\displaystyle= X1+a21‚ÄãX2+Z1subscriptùëã1subscriptùëé21subscriptùëã2subscriptùëç1\displaystyle X_{1}+a_{21}X_{2}+Z_{1} (55)
Y2subscriptùëå2\displaystyle Y_{2} =\displaystyle= a12‚ÄãX1+X2+Z2subscriptùëé12subscriptùëã1subscriptùëã2subscriptùëç2\displaystyle a_{12}X_{1}+X_{2}+Z_{2} (56)

where Z1subscriptùëç1Z_{1} and Z2subscriptùëç2Z_{2} are arbitrarily correlated zero mean, unit variance Gaussian random variables. Suppose the power constraints of X1subscriptùëã1X_{1} and X2subscriptùëã2X_{2} are P1subscriptùëÉ1P_{1} and P2subscriptùëÉ2P_{2}, respectively. For the conferencing channel with perfect echo cancellation, we have

Y~1=K1‚ÄãX1+Z~1,Y~2=K2‚ÄãX2+Z~2formulae-sequencesubscript~ùëå1subscriptùêæ1subscriptùëã1subscript~ùëç1subscript~ùëå2subscriptùêæ2subscriptùëã2subscript~ùëç2\displaystyle\tilde{Y}_{1}=K_{1}X_{1}+\tilde{Z}_{1},\hskip 28.45274pt\tilde{Y}_{2}=K_{2}X_{2}+\tilde{Z}_{2} (57)

where Z~1subscript~ùëç1\tilde{Z}_{1} and Z~2subscript~ùëç2\tilde{Z}_{2} are both zero mean, unit variance Gaussian variables. By reciprocity, we assume the channel coefficient K1=K2subscriptùêæ1subscriptùêæ2K_{1}=K_{2}. Since the computation of ‚Ñõ‚àósuperscript‚Ñõ\mathcal{R}^{*} is formidable, here we constrain all the inputs to be Gaussian distributed and set Q=œïùëÑitalic-œïQ=\phi in order to compare our region with ùí¢‚Ä≤superscriptùí¢‚Ä≤\mathcal{G}^{{}^{\prime}} in (5.9) of [2] and the capacity region of GVBC. We denote this modified region as ‚Ñõ‚Ñõ\mathcal{R}. Consider, that for certain Œ±t,Œ≤t,Œ≥t,Œ∏t,Œºt‚àà[0,1]subscriptùõºùë°subscriptùõΩùë°subscriptùõæùë°subscriptùúÉùë°subscriptùúáùë°01\alpha_{t},\beta_{t},\gamma_{t},\theta_{t},\mu_{t}\in[0,1], with Œ±t+Œ≤t+Œ≥t+Œ∏t+Œºt=1subscriptùõºùë°subscriptùõΩùë°subscriptùõæùë°subscriptùúÉùë°subscriptùúáùë°1\alpha_{t}+\beta_{t}+\gamma_{t}+\theta_{t}+\mu_{t}=1, where t=1,2ùë°12t=1,2, the following hold:

Vt=Vt‚Ä≤+Ut+Œ∏t‚ÄãPt‚ÄãSt,where‚ÄãVt‚Ä≤‚àºN‚Äã(0,Œ±t‚ÄãPt)formulae-sequencesubscriptùëâùë°subscriptsuperscriptùëâ‚Ä≤ùë°subscriptùëàùë°subscriptùúÉùë°subscriptùëÉùë°subscriptùëÜùë°similar-towheresubscriptsuperscriptùëâ‚Ä≤ùë°ùëÅ0subscriptùõºùë°subscriptùëÉùë°\displaystyle V_{t}=V^{\prime}_{t}+U_{t}+\sqrt{\theta_{t}P_{t}}S_{t},\hskip 5.69046pt\mbox{where}\hskip 5.69046ptV^{\prime}_{t}\sim N(0,\alpha_{t}P_{t}) (59)

After applying Fourier-Motzkin Elimination on those bounds (9)-(32), we find that for each set of (Œ±1,Œ≤1,Œ≥1,Œ∏1,Œº1)subscriptùõº1subscriptùõΩ1subscriptùõæ1subscriptùúÉ1subscriptùúá1(\alpha_{1},\beta_{1},\gamma_{1},\theta_{1},\mu_{1}) and (Œ±2,Œ≤2,Œ≥2,Œ∏2,Œº2)subscriptùõº2subscriptùõΩ2subscriptùõæ2subscriptùúÉ2subscriptùúá2(\alpha_{2},\beta_{2},\gamma_{2},\theta_{2},\mu_{2}), both S‚Äã(Z1)ùëÜsubscriptùëç1S(Z_{1}) and S‚Äã(Z2)ùëÜsubscriptùëç2S(Z_{2}) are delimited by straight lines of slope 0,‚àí12,‚àí1,‚àí2,‚àû012120,-\frac{1}{2},-1,-2,\infty as in the original HK region. Exhausting all the parameters between [0,1]01[0,1], and taking the convex hull of all those S‚Äã(Z1)ùëÜsubscriptùëç1S(Z_{1}) and S‚Äã(Z2)ùëÜsubscriptùëç2S(Z_{2}), we get the achievable region ‚Ñõ‚Ñõ\mathcal{R} for ICC in Fig.2.

Remarks:

1) When there is no conferencing between the two users, the achievable region reduces to the HK region. When the quality of the conferencing channel improves, it increases our achievable region for ICC within the limit of the capacity of GVBC.

2) When the channel coefficient is K1=K2=4subscriptùêæ1subscriptùêæ24K_{1}=K_{2}=4, the region ‚Ñõ‚Ñõ\mathcal{R} is already very close to the upper bound; when K1=K2=1subscriptùêæ1subscriptùêæ21K_{1}=K_{2}=1, which is equal to the channel coefficient of the transmitter to the receiver, cooperation achieves a slightly better rate region than independent transmission.

3) For the channel coefficient K1=K2=4subscriptùêæ1subscriptùêæ24K_{1}=K_{2}=4, the corresponding relay channels (i.e., one of the users only serves as a relay) are degraded, thus the intercepts of the bound at both axes are the capacities of respective relay channels.
